Ni-based catalysts prepared using layered double hydroxides (LDH) as precursors containing Mg and Ca are examined as dual-function materials for CO2 capture and methanation. X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, H2 temperature-programmed reduction, N2 adsorption, and scanning transmission electron microscopy analyses revealed that the LDH-derived Ni catalysts form porous structures of composite oxides (MgO-NiO) containing 5-nm-sized micropores and highly dispersed 5–10-nm-sized Ni-metal nanoparticles. The methanation performance is investigated under isothermal cyclic operation with an O2-containing gas (10%-CO2/5%-O2/bal.-He) and 20%-H2/bal.-He at 320 °C; the results indicate that the LDH-derived Ni catalysts containing Ca, Mg, and Al exhibit high methanation activities. Mg contributes to the stabilization of the porous structure and enhances the Ni-metal dispersion, while Ca provides effective CO2 adsorption and storage sites. After the 21st Conference of the Parties (COP21), the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) member states adopted the Paris Agreement, which involves limiting the increase in global average temperature to below 2 °C compared to pre-industrial levels; this requires virtually zero emissions of greenhouse gases in the second half of this century [1]. Although realizing energy efficiency via technological innovation and the active use of natural renewable energy are crucial to achieve this goal, issues exist with regard to renewable energy generation and distribution. Essentially, the supply of renewable energy, such as wind and solar power, is highly variable because of its dependence on external factors (climate, season, and area); moreover, the generation of massive surplus electricity is a concern. CO2 methanation using hydrogen produced via electrolysis has attracted considerable attention for the chemical storage of surplus electricity (power-to-gas schemes). Hashimoto et al. [2] proposed the earliest power-to-gas concept involving a global CO2 recycling system that combined seawater-electrolysis-based H2 production and CO2 methanation. Recent power-to-gas projects have mostly been established in Germany since the late 2000 s to convert surplus electric power into CH4, which can be distributed through the natural-gas grid. The first commercial-scale 6.3-MW CO2 methanation plants were launched by ETOGAS, in which CO2 from biogas plants was converted into high-purity CH4 (>93%) at an electric-power-to-methane efficiency of more than 50% [3]. The use of dual-function materials (DFMs), which integrate CO2 capture and CO2 conversion capabilities, is considered a novel CO2 emission reduction strategy. Notably, it is possible to directly convert the captured CO2 into valuable products using these materials. DFMs comprise alkali metal oxides or alkaline earth metal oxides (or their carbonates), which provide CO2 capture sites, and metal nanoparticles, which act as catalytic active sites for CO2 conversion. Methanation-type DFMs using CaO adsorbents were first reported by Duyar et al. [4]. The CaO adsorbent chemically adsorbs CO2 at relatively high temperatures of approximately 300 °C, which is a suitable temperature for the subsequent methanation reaction, thereby eliminating the need for temperature swing adsorption. Moreover, the heat released by the exothermic carbonation reaction (Eq. 1) during CO2 capture and the exothermic Sabatier reaction (Eq. 3) during CO2 methanation supplements the energy required for the endothermic decarboxylation reaction (Eq. 2). In this way, the system is thermally self-sustaining without the need for external heating. (1) CO 2 ( g ) + CaO ( s ) → CaCO 3 ( s ) , ∆ H 593 K = − 175 kJ / mol , (2) CaCO 3 ( s ) → CO 2 ( g ) + CaO ( s ) , ∆ H 593 K = 175 kJ / mol , (3) CO 2 ( g ) + 4 H 2 ( g ) → CH 4 ( g ) + 2 H 2 O ( g ) , ∆ H 593 K = − 178 kJ / mol , The integration of CO2 capture and methanation technologies into one reaction system and the utilization of the reaction heat for maintaining the temperature are expected to lead to systems that are more compact and efficient than systems in which the CO2 capture and methanation reactions are operated independently. Effective DFMs must contain both a CO2 adsorbent and a catalytically active component. Ru and Ni are typically employed as the catalytic metal species, with Ru being the most active metal for methanation [5]. Ru-based DFMs for methanation were first examined using a CaO adsorbent [4,6]. However, investigations into the selection of suitable alkali and alkaline earth metals for the CO2 adsorbent are ongoing [7–9]. Bermejo-López et al. [10] and Wang et al. [11,12] concluded that Na species can be suitably employed as the CO2 adsorbent. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy [13] and kinetics modeling [14] have revealed that the reaction mechanism of Ru/NaCO3/Al2O3 DFMs involves CO2 adsorption and desorption on highly dispersed Na2O species. Ni is also a candidate for the catalytic component of DFMs because of its high methanation activity and low cost [15–17]. However, Arellano-Treviño et al. [17] found that Ni-based DFMs exhibit a low methanation efficiency in an O2-containing atmosphere owing to Ni oxidation; interestingly, Ni–Ru bimetallic catalysts were noted to overcome this limitation [18]. Ni-based DFMs are also used in other CO2 conversion reactions, such as reverse water–gas shift reactions [19] and dry methane/ethane reforming [20]. DFMs have also attracted attention for CO2 capture from ambient air (direct air capture) because of their ability to adsorb diluted CO2 (on the order of hundreds of parts per million) [21,22]. This study was aimed at developing a Ni-based DFM with high CO2 capture capacity, CH4 selectivity, and O2 durability by focusing on a combination of Ni and alkaline earth metals in a layered double hydroxide (LDH) structure. LDHs are layered compounds with the formula [M2+ 1−x M3+ x (OH)2] x+[A n− x/n ·yH2O] x−, where the M2+ component of the hydroxide layers represents a divalent metal cation, such as Ni2+, Mg2+, Ca2+, and Zn2+; and M3+ represents a trivalent metal cation, such as Al3+ and Fe3+. The positive charge generated by replacing some of the divalent metal cations with trivalent cations is compensated by the intercalated anions (A n−; Cl−, NO3 −, and CO3 2−) in the intermediate layers. LDH-derived Ni-based catalysts, in which a LDH precursor is transformed into a porous structure via thermal decomposition and then activated to act as a methanation catalyst via reduction, exhibit high stability and performance for methanation [23–26]. The DFMs derived from these materials have several merits: (i) the distances between the CO2 capture sites of the alkaline earth metals (Mg, Ca) and the active redox sites of Ni for methanation can be decreased by compounding the precursors in the same hydroxide layer of the LDH; (ii) suitable morphologies can be constructed by modifying the solution pH, post-processing temperature, and type of intercalated anion [27]; (iii) the strength of the interactions between the metal (Ni) and support can be adjusted by modifying the composition of the cation layers; and (iv) additional functionality can be realized by doping other elements into the LDH solution [28–31]. In this study, we employed LDH-derived Ni-based DFMs as highly reactive Ni-based catalysts even in O2-rich atmospheres. Ni-based DFMs containing different cations were prepared using the LDH as a precursor, and the differences in structure and characteristics with respect to the presence or absence of cations were clarified. Cyclic CO2 adsorption and methanation tests were performed using these LDH-derived catalysts and a wet-impregnation-derived catalyst. A special focus was placed on the distances between the cations and the metal–support interactions. In this way, the LDH structure can be exploited to construct an ideal reaction field where the active sites are simultaneously highly dispersed and in close proximity to the CO2 storage sites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The LDH precursors were prepared using a co-precipitation method. The samples were denoted according to their constituent elements, molar ratios, and post-treatment strategy as Ni x Ca y Mg z Al2-X (x + y + z = 6; compositions: Mg6Al2, Ni6Al2, Ni2Mg4Al2, Ni2Ca4Al2, Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2; X = LDH, O, or R). An aqueous NaOH solution was added dropwise to this mixture under vigorous stirring to adjust the pH to 11, and the resulting solution was stirred for 3 h at 65 °C, yielding a precipitate that was aged for 15 h at 65 °C. Calcined catalysts (-O) were obtained by thermally treating the -LDH samples for 5 h in air at 500 °C. Reduced catalysts (-R) were obtained by thermally treating the -LDH samples for 5 h under a 5%-H2/bal.-N2 environment at 500 °C. A catalyst containing 30 wt% Ni, 15 wt% CaO, and 15 wt% MgO impregnated on a γ-Al2O3 support was prepared as a reference sample (Ni-imp). Two- and three-stage weight losses were observed under the calcining and reducing conditions, respectively. By considering the initial LDH chemical composition (Table S1) and results of previous studies [25,29], the first weight loss of ∼9–12% of the total weight in the 50–250 °C region was assigned to the decomposition of intercalated water molecules. The second weight loss of ∼25–35% of the total weight in the 250–450 °C range was attributed to the decomposition of intercalated hydroxides and carbonates or nitrates. Therefore, these results indicate that the LDHs could not maintain their structures at 500 °C. The decomposition of intercalated carbonates and nitrates in the Ni-containing LDHs occurred at lower temperatures than those in Mg6Al2-LDH (Fig. S3), indicating the thermal instability of the structures of the Ni- or Ca-containing LDHs. The decomposition of intercalated carbonates in the Ca-containing LDHs was more complicated than that in the other LDHs. For example, under calcining conditions, the weight of Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-LDH sharply decreased in the 300–400 °C region, then slowly decreased in the 400–500 °C region, indicating two-stage decomposition through CaCO3. The third weight loss in the 400–800 °C range was observed only for Ni-containing LDHs under reducing conditions. This weight loss was assigned to the reduction of oxidized Ni compounds to Ni metal. This weight loss steadily continued until the maximum temperature of 800 °C, indicating the difficulty involved in completely reducing oxidized Ni compounds below 800 °C. The XRD patterns of several LDHs are shown in Fig. S4. The diffraction peaks at 11°, 23°, 35°, 39°, 46°, 48°, 61°, 63°, and 66° derive from the LDH structure (hydrotalcite, JCPDS No. 01–082–8041). The prepared LDHs formed single-phase structures, except for Ni2Ca4Al2-LDH, which formed a double-phase LDH structure. The low- and high-angle LDH peaks in the Ni2Ca4Al2-LDH spectrum were attributed to the Ca-containing LDH (JCPDS card No. 00–054–0849) and Ni-containing LDH (takovite, JCPDS No. 01–084–3868), respectively. Moreover, diffraction peaks representing CaCO3 (calcite, JCPDS No. 01–072–4582) and Ca3Al2(OH)12 (katoite, JCPDS No. 01–074–3032) were observed in the XRD pattern of the Ni2Ca4Al2-LDH (Fig. S5). Ca3Al2(OH)12 was also observed in the XRD pattern of Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-LDH (Fig. S6). The larger ionic radius of Ca2+ (1.00 Å, coordination number = 6) compared to those of the other M2+ and M3+ elements (Mg2+: 0.72 Å; Ni2+: 0.69 Å; Al3+: 0.54 Å, coordination number = 6) hindered the generation of a single-phase Ca-rich LDH. The intensities of the diffraction peaks representing the LDHs, as shown in Fig. S4, were diminished after the calcination and reduction treatments, indicating that the LDH structure was completely decomposed after both treatments; this observation is consistent with the TGA results (Fig. 1 and S3). The magnified XRD patterns of the calcined catalysts in a narrow 2θ range (40–50°) are shown in Fig. 2b, with a focus on the strongest reflection from MgO(200); the corresponding peak positions are listed in Table 1. In Fig. 2b, shoulder peaks are not visible and the peak positions are dependent on the Mg and Ni contents, indicating that MgO and NiO formed a MgO–NiO composite oxide with the MgO and NiO phases influenced with each other. The higher the Ca content, the weaker the intensity of the diffraction peak derived from the periclase-like structure. This indicates that Ca reduced the crystallinity of the MgO–NiO composite oxide. Fig. 3a shows XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts, which contain diffraction peaks derived from Ni metal (44° and 51°) in addition to MgO–NiO (as highlighted in Fig. 2a). Peaks derived from CaCO3, Ca12Al14O33, and Ca3Al2O6 (JCPDS card No.00–033–0251) were also observed in the XRD pattern of the Ni2Ca4Al2-R catalyst (Fig. S8), with weak peaks of Ca12Al14O33 also observed in the XRD pattern of Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R. Magnified XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts with a focus on the Ni-metal diffraction peaks are shown in Fig. 3b. The diffraction peaks representing Ni(111) were observed as shoulder peaks in the MgO–NiO diffraction patterns. The average Ni-metal crystalline sizes of the reduced catalysts were estimated using the Scherrer equation. The results are shown in Table 1. The XRD patterns of the Mg-rich catalysts had weaker Ni-metal diffraction intensities, leading to difficulties in estimating the Ni metal crystalline size of Ni2Mg4Al2-R. This result indicates that MgO strongly interacted with Ni to maintain its oxide form. The XRD results for the calcined and reduced catalysts are summarized as follows: (i) NiO and MgO formed a MgO–NiO composite oxide, and Mg strongly influenced Ni-metal formation; and (ii) the crystallinity of the MgO–NiO phase was affected by the presence of Ca, indicating that Ca possibly existed in or near MgO–NiO. These conclusions suggest that Ca, Mg, and Ni co-exist in the catalysts. Consequently, they should provide an ideal reaction field with CO2 adsorption sites and CO2 reduction sites situated close to each other. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of all the calcined and reduced catalysts are shown in Figs. S9 and S10. Table 1 shows the specific surface areas (S BET) and pore volumes of the calcined and reduced catalysts. Both types of catalysts exhibited type-IV adsorption/desorption isotherms in terms of the IUPAC classification, with 5-nm-sized mesopores on average. This indicates that the thermal-treatment-induced collapsed LDHs formed mesoporous structures. This pore structure was formed independently of the atmosphere used in the thermal treatment (calcining or reducing conditions). For the Ca-containing catalysts, the reduced catalysts (Ni2Ca4Al2-R and Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R) had larger S BET values and pore volumes than their calcined counterparts (Ni2Ca4Al2-O and Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-O, respectively). This suggested that the volume of CaCO3 decreased by decomposition into CaO. Alternatively, the volume of CaCO3, which was influenced as inhibitors that blocked the internal pores of the porous MgO–NiO composite oxide, may have been decreased by reduction treatment. The reduced catalysts show promising results for the CO2 adsorption and catalytic reactions; thus, further characterizations and activity tests were focused on these catalysts. This suggests that CO2 is present in the form of stable carbonates in the catalysts containing large amounts of Ca. 3.3 Temperature programmed experiments (H2-TPR and CO2-TPD) Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPR profiles of the reduced catalysts after pretreatment in an O2-containing atmosphere at 500 °C. All the profiles exhibit two H2 consumption peaks. H2 consumption by the reduced catalysts is primarily attributed to the reduction of NiO, because almost all other components capable of consuming H2 (such as CaCO3) at temperatures below 500 °C were removed by the reduction treatment during catalyst preparation. The first set of peaks in the 200–450 °C range represent NiO that weakly interacts with the MgO–NiO support, which transform into Ni-metal nanoparticles via the precipitation of the MgO–NiO composite oxide upon thermal reduction at 500 °C. The second set of peaks in the 450–850 °C range correspond to the reduction of NiO that strongly interacts with the MgO–NiO support, which could not be precipitated by reduction at 500 °C. The presence of two different reduction peaks of NiO has been reported previously. Wierzbicki et al. [23] investigated the MgO-to-NiO reducibility by acquiring H2-TPR profiles of catalysts with different Ni/Mg molar ratios. In Fig. 6, the intensity of the first peak is lower in the Ni2Mg4Al2-R profile than those in the Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R and Ni2Ca4Al2-R profiles. The amounts of Ni metal and NiO in the catalysts, as well as the ratios to the total Ni content, were estimated from the areas of the two H2-TPR peaks. The results are listed in Table 2. The amount of Ni-metal nanoparticles in the Ni2Mg4Al2-R catalyst was presumed to be lower than that in the other reduced catalysts because of the strong MgO–NiO interactions. The Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R profile had a single component in the first peak, whereas H2 consumption was derived from two structures in Ni2Ca4Al2-R. The reduction peak temperature of the precipitated NiO species was found to be related to the NiO particle size. Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R and the other reduced catalysts contained homogeneous Ni-metal nanoparticles, as shown in Fig. 4b, whereas Ni2Ca4Al2-R contained not only Ni-metal nanoparticles but also bulky Ni-metal particles. The second set of reduction peak temperatures was ordered as follows: Ni6Al2-R ≈ Ni2Ca4Al2-R < Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R < Ni2Mg4Al2-R. These results also support the existence of strong MgO–NiO interactions, as discussed in the analysis of Figs. 1 and 3. In the CO2 concentration profiles obtained during CO2 capture (Fig. 8a), the time at which the CO2 release by each catalyst starts follows the order Ni-imp, Ni2Mg4Al2-R, Ni2Ca4Al2-R, and Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R. In terms of the amount of captured CO2 at the time at which CO2 was released from the reactor outlet, Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R exhibited the largest CO2 capacity throughout the cycling experiments (Fig. 9a), with 0.65 and 0.29 mmol/g-cat of CO2 captured during the first and tenth cycles, respectively. Fig. 8b shows magnified CO2 concentration profiles corresponding to the methanation step. CO2 desorption occurred during the purging and methanation steps, with comparatively large amounts of CO2 being desorbed from the Ni2Mg4Al2-R and Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R catalysts (Fig. 9b). This indicates that the Mg-derived CO2 capture sites are weaker than their Ca-derived equivalents, which led to weakly adsorbed CO2 being released upon changes in the CO2 partial pressure. Fig. 9e shows the CH4 selectivity of each catalyst. CO (molar mass = 28.01 g/mol) can potentially be produced by the H2 reduction of CO2; however, the formation of CO was almost non-existent according to observed from the lack of intensity from a molar mass of 28 g/mol. Therefore, the product obtained by reducing the captured CO2 was confirmed to be mostly CH4. From the definition of CH4 selectivity (Eq. 8), the smaller the amount of desorbed CO2, the higher the selectivity of CH4. Ni2Ca4Al2-R showed the highest CH4 selectivity of the catalysts because it had the lowest amount of desorbed CO2. The O2 concentration profiles in Fig. 8c indicate that Ni2Ca4Al2-R consumed more O2 than the other catalysts, and Fig. 9c shows that Ni2Mg4Al2-R and Ni-imp reacted minimally with O2 throughout the ten investigated cycles. The low O2 consumption by the Mg-rich Ni2Mg4Al2-R catalyst is presumably related to the increased stability of NiO by the strong support interactions at high MgO contents, which would decrease the number of Ni-metal nanoparticles precipitated during the reduction treatment. Fig. 8d shows CH4 formation profiles, which indicate that CH4 was produced immediately after the introduction of H2 and continued being generated until the end of the methanation step. Ni2Ca4Al2-R exhibited the highest CH4 formation peak intensity, followed by Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R, Ni-imp, and Ni2Mg4Al2-R; however, Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R yielded the largest overall amount of CH4 (0.28 mmol/g-cat for the first cycle and 0.26 mmol/g for the tenth cycle), followed by Ni2Ca4Al2-R, Ni2Mg4Al2-R, and Ni-imp. Figs. 9c and 9d reveals an intimate relationship between the oxygen consumption and methanation activity. The Ni-metal nanoparticles, observed at low temperatures (<500 °C) in the H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 7), are believed to be reduced/oxidized alternatively under the cyclic reduction/oxidation processes. The decrease in the O2 consumption of Ni2Ca4Al2-R and Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R is possibly related to the decreased CH4 formation, based on the increase in the amount of NiO species that cannot be easily reduced. Arellano-Treviño et al. [17] reported that CH4 is not generated when Ni-based catalysts are exposed to O2 for long durations (considerably longer than in the current experiment). Therefore, the oxidative durability of these Ni catalysts must be examined by further durability tests in the future. H2O was formed in both the CO2 capture and methanation steps (Fig. 8e). The formation of H2O in the CO2 capture step indicates a reaction between CO2 and Ca(OH)2 [16]. Considerable H2O formation was achieved by the Ni2Ca2Mg2Al2-R catalyst in this step, indicating that this catalyst captured more CO2 than the other catalysts·H2O formation during methanation is derived from the methanation reaction of CaCO3 and the reduction of re-oxidized NiO species. The Ni2Ca4Al2-R catalyst exhibited the largest amount of H2O formation in this step, which is consistent with its high methanation activity and O2 consumption (Figs. 9c and 9d). From the results of the catalyst characterization and catalytic cycling tests, the function of each component of the Ni x Ca y Mg z Al2-X catalysts is explained henceforth. Ni provides active redox sites for methanation. In this regard, reduction treatment at 500 °C is necessary to precipitate a sufficient amount of Ni-metal particles with adequate methanation activity. With high-temperature reduction treatments (above 500 °C), Ni-metal particles precipitate from NiO, as seen from the TGA results in Fig. 1. However, the treatment can increase the Ni particle size and promote the formation of other composite oxides, such as MgAl2O4 [31] and calcium aluminates. Mg seems to play a role in the stable formation of the LDH structure, as evidenced by the single crystal phase of the Mg-rich LDHs, in contrast to the dual-phase Ca-containing LDH. In addition, the presence of MgO leads to a reduction in the Ni-metal particle size. The XPS and H2-TPR results indicate that there is a strong interaction between MgO and NiO, and this interaction seems to reduce the Ni-metal particle size to suppress the precipitation of Ni by H2 reduction. Ca primarily provides strong CO2 adsorption sites, as evidenced by the high amounts of CO2 captured by the Ca-rich catalysts. The Ca contained in the porous structures of MgO–NiO composite oxides exhibits high storage and methanation abilities because of its proximity to Ni-metal nanoparticles. However, not all of the Ca was sufficiently compounded with MgO–NiO; the remaining Ca forms segregated calcium oxide, calcium carbonate, and calcium aluminate particles owing to its larger ion radius compared to those of the other elements. A catalyst with enhanced activity can be obtained by confining Ca to the porous oxide structure by modifying the synthesis method and heat treatment conditions for the LDH precursor. Al2O3 is expected to increase the porosity and heat resistance of the catalyst as an anti-sintering agent [34]. However, to clarify the role of Al, detailed studies are necessary, such as comparing catalysts with different Al contents and performing structural analyses of Al-containing materials. 4 Conclusion The structures and performance of LDH-derived Ni-based catalysts for CO2 capture and methanation were investigated. Fig. 10 shows an illustration of the LDH-derived Ni catalyst. The Ni catalyst obtained by reducing Ni-LDHs formed a porous structure of a composite oxide (MgO–NiO), which contained Ca for CO2 storage and highly dispersed 5–10-nm-sized Ni-metal particles. The catalyst constructed with this structure exhibited superior performance owing to the following benefits achieved under the CO2 capture and methanation reaction conditions: (i) highly dispersed active sites for CO2 methanation, and (ii) proximity of CO2 methanation active sites and CO2 storage sites. Investigation of the Ni catalysts with different composition ratios indicated that catalysts containing Ni, Ca, and Mg were highly active. Mg is thought to affect the stabilization of the porous structure, promote the formation of Ni metal inside the porous structure, and retain fine grain sizes of the Ni metal. coredata.dc:description: Ni-based catalysts prepared using layered double hydroxides (LDH) as precursors containing Mg and Ca are examined as dual-function materials for CO2 capture and methanation. X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, H2 temperature-programmed reduction, N2 adsorption, and scanning transmission electron microscopy analyses revealed that the LDH-derived Ni catalysts form porous structures of composite oxides (MgO-NiO) containing 5-nm-sized micropores and highly dispersed 5–10-nm-sized Ni-metal nanoparticles. The methanation performance is investigated under isothermal cyclic operation with an O2-containing gas (10%-CO2/5%-O2/bal.-He) and 20%-H2/bal.-He at 320 °C; the results indicate that the LDH-derived Ni catalysts containing Ca, Mg, and Al exhibit high methanation activities. Mg contributes to the stabilization of the porous structure and enhances the Ni-metal dispersion, while Ca provides effective CO2 adsorption and storage sites.
coredata.dc:title: Layered-double-hydroxide-based Ni catalyst for CO2 capture and methanation
